rawText.$: 1. T. Dietz, E. Ostrom, P. C. Stern, The struggle to govern the commons. Science 362, 1907- 1912 (2003).
2. J. Rockström et al., A safe operating space for humanity. Nature 461, 472-475 (2009).
3. S. Barrett,. Why Cooperate? The Incentives to Supply Global Public Goods (Oxford Univ. Press, Oxford, 2007).
4. C. Carraro, D. Siniscalco, Eds., New Directions in the Economic Theory of the Environment. (Cambridge Univ. Press, New York, 1997).
5. G. Hardin, The tragedy of the commons. Science 162, 1243-1248 (1968).
6. S. A. Levin, Fragile Dominion: Complexity and the Commons (Perseus Books, 1999).
7. E. Ostrom, J. Burger, C. B. Field, R. B. Norgaard, D. Policansky. Revisiting the commons: local lessons, global challenges. Science 284, 278-282.
8. K. A. Brekke, O. Johansson-Stenman, The behavioral economics of climate change. Oxf. Rev. Econ. Pol. 24, 280-297 (2008).
9. M. Inman, The climate change game. Nature Rep. Clim. Change 3, 130-133 (2009).
10. J. Ledyard, in Handbook of Experimental Economics, J. H. Kagel, A. E. Roth, Eds. (Princeton Univ. Press, Princeton, NJ, 1995), pp. 111-194.
11. B. Sturm, J. Weimann, Experiments in environmental economics and some close relatives. J. Econ. Surv. 20, 419-457 (2006).
12. E. Ostrom, in Polycentric Games and Institutions: Readings from the Workshop in Political Theory and Policy Analysis, M. D. McGinnis, Ed. (Univ. of Michigan Press, Michigan, 2000), chap. 16.
13. E. Fehr, S. Gächter, Cooperation and punishment in public goods experiments. Am. Econ. Rev. 90, 980-994 (2000).
14. Ö Gürerk, B. Irlenbusch, B. Rockenbach, The competitive advantage of sanctioning institutions. Science 312, 108-111 (2006).
15. U. Fischbacher, S. Gächter, Social preferences, beliefs, and the dynamics of free riding in public goods experiments. Am. Econ. Rev. 100 , 541-556 (2010).

16. M. Milinski, R. D. Sommerfeld, H.-J. Krambeck, F. A. Reed, J. Marotzke, The collective-risk social dilemma and the prevention of simulated dangerous climate change. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105, 2291-2294 (2008).
17. A. Dreber, M. A. Nowak, Gambling for global goods. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105, 2261-2261 (2008).
18. S. Barrett, Environment and Statecraft: The Strategy of Environmental Treaty-making (Oxford Univ. Press, Oxford, 2003).
19. J. Tollefson, Last-minute deal saves climate talks, Nature 468, 875-876 (2010).
20. E. Kintisch, A. Regalado, Cancún Delegates See the Trees Through a Forest of Hot Air. Science 330, 1597 (2010).
21. A. Lange, A. Löschel, C. Vogt, A. Ziegler, On the self-interested use of equity in international climate negotiations. Eur. Econ. Rev. 54, 359-375 (2010).
22. J. P. Sheposh, P. S. Jr. Gallo, Asymmetry of payoff structure and cooperative behavior in the prisoner's dilemma game. J. Conflict Resolution 17, 321-333 (1973).
23. A. Alesina, E. La Ferrara, Participation in heterogeneous communities. Q. J. Econ. 115, 847-904 (2000).
24. D. L. Costa, M. E. Kahn, Civic engagement and community heterogeneity: an economists perspective. Perspect. Politics 1, 103-112 (2003).
25. L. R. Anderson, J. M. Mellor, J. Milyo, Inequality and public good provision: an experimental analysis. J. Socio-Econ. 37, 1010-1028 (2008).
26. E. Ostrom, R. Gardner, J. Walker, Rules, Games, and Common-pool Resources (Univ. of Michigan Press, 1994).
27. S. Hackett, E. Schlager, J. Walker, The role of communication in resolving commons dilemmas: experimental evidence with heterogeneous appropriators. J. Environ. Econ. Manage 27, 99-126 (1994).
28. J.-M. Baland, J.-P. Platteau, in Inequality, Cooperation and Environmental Sustainability, J.M. Baland, P. Bardhan, S. Bowles, Eds. (Princeton Univ. Press, Princeton, NJ, 2007), chap. 2.
29. J. T. Roberts, B. C. Parks, A Climate of Injustice: Global Inequality, North-South Politics and Climate Policy (MIT Press, Cambridge, MA, 2006).
30. U. T. Srinivasan, et al, The debt of nations and the distribution of ecological impacts from human activities. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105, 1768-1773 (2008).
32. J. Nash, Equilibrium points in N-person games. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A., 36, 48-49 (1950).
33. S. D. Levitt, J. A. List, What do laboratory experiments measuring social preferences reveal about the real world? J. Econ. Perspect. 21, 153-174 (2007).
34. R. E. Kasperson et al., in Ecosystems and Human Well-Being. Current State and Trends, R. M. Hassan, R. Scholes, N. Ash, Eds. (Island Press: 2005), vol. 1, chap. 6.

35. W. N. Adger, et al., in Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, M. Parry, O. F. Canziani, J. Palutikof, P. van der Linden, C. E. Hanson, Eds. (Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, U.K.), chap. 17.
36. G. Kallis, Droughts. Annu. Rev. Environ. Resour. 33, 85 -118 (2008).
37. J.-M. Baland, J.-P., Platteau, Wealth inequality and efficiency in the commons. Oxf. Econ. Pap. 49, 451-482 (1997).
38. T. L. Cherry, S. Kroll, J. F. Shogren, The impact of endowment heterogeneity and origin on public good contributions: evidence from the lab. J. Econ. Behav. Organ. 57, 357-365 (2007).
39. S. Kroll, T. L. Cherry, T.L., J. F. Shogren, The impact of endowment heterogeneity and origin on contributions in best-shot public good games. Exp. Econ. 10, 411-428 (2007).
S1. J. Ledyard, in Handbook of Experimental Economics, J. H. Kagel, A. E. Roth, Eds. (Princeton Univ. Press, Princeton, NJ, 1995), pp. 111-194.

S3. M. Milinski, R. D. Sommerfeld, H.-J. Krambeck, F. A. Reed, J. Marotzke, The collective-risk social dilemma and the prevention of simulated dangerous climate change. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105 2291-2294 (2008).
S4. U. Fischbacher, Z-tree: Zurich toolbox for ready-made economic experiments, Exp. Econ. 10, 171-178 (2007).
